altnotes:
Solid Steel (2nd January) We kick off 2015 with a mix from BNJMN. Following releases on Rush Hour, Svetlana and more recently Technicolour and Delsin, the British producer delivers a mix to shake off any New Year hangovers. It's straight in with forthcoming music from Rezzett on Trilogy Tapes and recent tracks from Bodem, Svreca and Marco Zenker. Then it's the James Holden remix for Perc & Avus, Voiski on LIES, Kowton and closing with former guest Chris Carter alongside Throbbing Gristle member Cosey with a track from their Techno Primitiv album from 1985.

 In hour 2 we welcome Discodromo, the Italian duo based in Berlin who also founded the Cocktail d'Amore label alongside Berghain resident Boris Dolinski. Although down a notch in tempo, this mix retains the quality throughout. We don't have a tracklist, but it's full of their trademark sound that successfully treads the line between cosmic disco and house.

Solid Steel (9th January) DK is back for his first mix of 2015 and after a brief intro from Doug Carn, it's straight into a batch of forthcoming music from Glenn Astro & Max Graef, Dan Snake and Anthony Naples from his album coming out on Four Tet's Text label. It's another spin for the huge Roots by Romare and classic deep house from 1995 from Marc Kinchen and Chez Damier under his Andthoney alias. Mix of the Year winner Clap! Clap! is remixed by Lurka Obeah, followed by a host of giveaways from Seven Davis Jr, Alex Patchwork, Photay and the Hudson Mohawke remix of Four Tet. Then more new music with Soundbwoy Killah and Beat Spacek with a track from the Modern Streets album out in 2 weeks, plus there's always time for another Fela Kuti track.

Our guest in Hour 2 is Rita Maia who hosts her weekly Saturday night show 'Sine of the Times' on the excellent Resonance FM and drops a mix with sounds from her native Lisbon and other exclusive unreleased bits. This is what she had to say;
"This Solid Steel mix, i wanted to include a lot of new sounds that have been circulating and mutating in a very underground circuit around Lisbon for the last 10 years, with influences of Kuduru, Tarracho and other things but very unique of that european city & definitely have a familiar feel.
I also think they have a similar feel to some of the UK sound and sound system culture, and having worked in projects in the outskirts of town before moving to London 12 years ago, it's special to play stuff that's made on such a diy way in times when everything is so predicted and polished in this industry. Most stuff is not even mastered properly but the rhythms are really quite obsessive.Â 

I get sent stuff since my show at London Resonance FM is syndicated there on a Friday night too via Radio Oxigenio. Other things are from digging online, most of it made by very young people who are doing their own thing and not bothered about sending it to anyone, so quite difficult to get.
Principe Label is doing a brilliant work to promote these sounds outside of the outskirts, some of the producers on the label in there are, Nigga Fox, Marfox & Maboku.Â 

Other things in the mix are by producers i've been playing loads in gigs like italian producer Khalab who recorded a mix for my show last year and Clap Clap, Emma, etc and some sounds from producers in south Africa and Mocambique, which are always close links to my home town where i grew up.Â "

session_name: Beat Spacek x Kutmah, Drift Record Shop
altnotes:
Solid Steel (30th January) With the brand new Beat Spacek album Modern Streets dropping this week, what better time to highlight the depth and quality of Steve Spacek\'s back catalogue and history of innovating in electronic music. The original Spacek trio music dates from 2001 and still sounds fresh and futuristic today, and his collaborations with the likes of Mark Pritchard and J Dilla, alongside his myriad solo productions under various monikers have been consistently and singularly brilliant. Kutmah (Sketchbook / IZWID) is one of our favourite selectors and DJs. His insatiable appetite for new music and his knowledge and passion for heritage sounds, teamed with the fact that he\'s a huge fan of Steve\'s music over the years made him the perfect candidate to do this mix. So here it is...Beat Spacek x Kutmah: Classics, collabs & unreleased heat from Steve Spacek\'s epic catalogue selected & mixed by Kutmah.

In Hour 2 this week we kick off a new regular feature for Solid Steel - Record Store Residency. Launching off the back of our successful RSD 2014 special, each month we\'ll be asking some of the best record shops from around the world to contribute a 60 minute mix, showcasing the music they love. First up it\'s Drift Record Shop from Devon in the UK, who deliver us a mix and told us \"The shop curation is pretty scatty, so to avoid too much of a discordant listen we focused primarily on drum machines, synths, pianos and organs.\" Music on offer from Oneohtrix Point Never, Romare, Martyn, Radiohead, Four Tet and The Gaslamp Killer for your Friday afternoon listening pleasure.

Solid Steel (30th January) We welcome Mike Simonetti in Hour 1 this week, who grew up on New York 80's hardcore punk and went on to form Troubleman Unlimited, Italians Do It Better and now has a new project 'Pale Blue', which is a collaboration with Elizabeth Wight of the band Silver Hands. The mix concentrates on quality over quantity, opening with some words from Henry Rollins from 1985 and delving into some vintage acid and Chicago House from DJ ESP, DJ Hyperactive and Paul Johnson. He described his mix as "music for the dark illegal parties with no emergency exits"

In Hour 2 it's a mix by Rob Sevier from Numero Group, the record label that digs deeper than most to lovingly reissue rare and long forgotten gems. The mix starts with their latest treasure, Universal Togetherness Band and moves through some ultra rare soul from the likes of Aged in Harmony, Morris Lewis, Everyday People, Broken Glass, James P Taylor and 'Try Me' by Wee that was also reissued by Numero Group. We touch on Latin with Larry T & the family, the mighty Harlem River Drive and Traffic Sound, before closing on a psych tip with Sir Stanley and Muse. Check out their full catalogue at http://www.numerogroup.com
link3: Solid Steel Radio Show 6/2/2015 Part 1 + 2 - Mike Simonetti by Solid Steel on Mixcloud
